study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of oral L-carnosine supplementation on quality of life and exercise performance in patients with stable chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: L-carnosine supplementation improved 6-minute walking test distance, quality-of-life scores, peak VO2, VO2 at anaerobic threshold, and peak exercise workload compared to controls. The study concluded that L-carnosine has beneficial effects on exercise performance and quality of life in stable CHF.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with stable CHF and severe left-ventricular systolic dysfunction on optimal medical therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether nonhydrolyzed carnosine and related compounds could slow telomere shortening and aging processes, particularly in tissues prone to proliferative senescence.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine may help maintain telomere length, potentially slowing aging and improving survival, with implications for age-related eye disorders and overall longevity. Carnosine's effects may be mediated through histamine-related neurotransmission and antiaging physiological functions.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (preliminary longitudinal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of carnosine and its derivatives in neuroprotection, cognitive function enhancement, and their potential therapeutic effects against neurodegeneration, depression, and intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that carnosine and its derivatives exhibit neuroprotective, anti-glycation, and anti-aging properties, with potential benefits for cognitive function, depression, and neurodegenerative diseases. They also highlighted the role of carnosine in histamine-mediated neurotransmission and its therapeutic applications in various formulations.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals and those with cognitive decline, depression, or neurodegenerative conditions.
effective_dosage: 1% N-acetylcarnosine lubricant eye drops, 1% carcinine lubricant eye drops, and specific patented nutraceutical composition (Can-C Plus™).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Carnosine and related compounds in regulating telomere shortening, telomerase activity, and cellular senescence to potentially slow aging and treat age-related disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that non-hydrolyzed Carnosine and related compounds may help maintain telomere length, slow cellular senescence, and potentially mitigate age-related conditions such as eye disorders, diabetes, sarcopenia, and neurodegenerative diseases.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals and subjects under physical stress or exhausting exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carnosine, delivered via 1% N-acetylcarnosine lubricant eye drops, could reduce telomere shortening in lens cells, improve visual function, and influence neuroendocrine pathways related to aging and cataract prevention.
results_summary: Carnosine reduced telomere shortening in lens cells under oxidative stress and improved visual acuity and glare sensitivity in older adults and cataract patients. It also showed potential neuroendocrine effects via histamine conversion in the hypothalamus, suggesting broader anti-aging benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults and older subjects with cataracts.
effective_dosage: 1% N-acetylcarnosine lubricant eye drops (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether non-hydrolyzed carnosine and related compounds could slow telomere shortening and aging processes, particularly in tissues affected by proliferative senescence.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine and carcinine may help maintain telomere length, potentially slowing aging and improving survival, with specific applications in age-related eye disorders and overall health.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (longitudinal studies mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of polaprezinc (containing L-carnosine and zinc) in an 8-week treatment for chronic pressure ulcers.
results_summary: Polaprezinc significantly improved Pressure Ulcer Scale for Healing (PUSH) scores within 1 week, with 11 out of 14 patients healing completely by 8 weeks. Serum zinc levels increased, while copper levels and copper/zinc ratios decreased, with one case of worsened preexisting copper deficiency.
population_specificity: Patients with stage II-IV pressure ulcers persisting for ≥8 weeks (14 participants, mean age 68.4 years).
effective_dosage: 150 mg/day (116 mg L-carnosine + 34 mg zinc) orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether carnosine, as a methylglyoxal scavenger, could mitigate biochemical events linked to Parkinson's disease pathology and assess its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine scavenges methylglyoxal and influences biochemical processes associated with Parkinson's disease, with double-blind, placebo-controlled trials showing beneficial outcomes in humans.
population_specificity: Humans (specific demographic not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a zinc-carnosine chelate compound (Polaprezinc) enema could accelerate mucosal healing in patients with active ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The study found that Polaprezinc significantly improved endoscopic scores in the rectum, sigmoid colon, and descending colon, and clinical response or remission was significantly better in the PZ group (71%) compared to the placebo group (10%).
population_specificity: 28 patients with active ulcerative colitis at The Jikei University Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological role, properties, and potential therapeutic and performance-enhancing uses of carnosine.
results_summary: Carnosine demonstrated beneficial effects on the organism, including antioxidant, protective, chelating, and anti-glycation activities, potentially aiding in the prevention and treatment of diseases like diabetes, neurodegenerative disorders, and cancers. It also showed promise in improving athletic performance by maintaining acid-base balance in muscles.
population_specificity: Laboratory animals and humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of carnosine mimetics in inhibiting glycation reactions and mitigating diabetic complications.
results_summary: The study found that carnosine mimetics act as antioxidants, deglycating agents, and inhibitors of protein cross-linking, with potential benefits in managing Type 2 Diabetes complications.
population_specificity: Patients with Type 2 Diabetes (NIDDM) and associated complications (nephropathy, retinopathy, neuropathy, atherosclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore carnosine's potential therapeutic effects in protecting against methylglyoxal (MG) reactivity and preventing neurotoxin formation, particularly in the context of neurodegeneration and diabetes.
results_summary: The study suggests carnosine may scavenge MG, potentially protecting against neurotoxicity and preventing the formation of ADTIQ, a neurotoxin linked to Parkinson's disease (PD) and diabetes. Nasal administration is proposed to bypass serum carnosinase degradation, enhancing therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical focus on neurodegeneration and diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether non-hydrolyzed carnosine and carcinine could modulate telomerase activity, provide redox regulation, and protect telomeres from attrition under oxidative stress caused by cigarette smoke.
results_summary: The study found that non-hydrolyzed carnosine and carcinine had greater bioavailability than pure l-carnosine, detoxified harmful compounds in tobacco smoke, and protected against smoke-induced disease and inflammation. These compounds showed potential therapeutic utility in inflammatory lung diseases linked to smoking.
population_specificity: Smokers and individuals exposed to cigarette smoke-induced oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of zinc-induced neurotoxicity and assess whether carnosine could inhibit neuronal death caused by excess zinc.
results_summary: Carnosine and histidine inhibited zinc-induced neuronal death in GT1-7 cells and suppressed the expression of ER-stress and calcium-related genes (GADD34, p8, and Arc), suggesting potential neuroprotective effects against zinc toxicity.
population_specificity: Immortalized hypothalamic neurons (GT1-7 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polaprezinc (a zinc-L-carnosine chelate) is effective in treating small-bowel injuries caused by long-term low-dose aspirin use.
results_summary: The study found that polaprezinc significantly reduced the number of reddened lesions and erosions/ulcers in the small bowel compared to the control group, suggesting efficacy in mitigating aspirin-induced injury.
population_specificity: Patients under long-term (>3 months) low-dose aspirin treatment with small-bowel injuries detected via capsule endoscopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if L-carnosine supplementation could improve pain, cognition, and fatigue in Gulf War illness (GWI) patients.
results_summary: Carnosine significantly improved WAIS-R cognitive test scores and reduced diarrhea associated with irritable bowel syndrome, but had no significant effects on fatigue, pain, hyperalgesia, or other outcomes.
population_specificity: 25 Gulf War veterans with GWI (Chronic Multisymptom Illness).
effective_dosage: 500 mg, 1000 mg, and 1500 mg, escalated at 4-week intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carnosine could normalize reduced polyamine levels in erythrocytes of patients with hypertonic discirculatory encephalopathy and explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Carnosine addition to the treatment protocol normalized putrescine and spermine levels in patients with chronic brain ischemia. The study suggests carnosine may work by trapping acrolein and compensating NMDA-receptor excitotoxicity.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertonic discirculatory encephalopathy and chronic brain ischemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of histamine-related agents, including carnosine, as therapeutic targets for cerebral ischemia.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that carnosine shows potential for cerebral ischemia therapy, likely due to its role in modulating histamine pathways, which alleviate neuronal damage, reduce excitotoxicity, and promote neurogenesis. However, molecular and pathophysiological aspects remain unresolved.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cerebral ischemia context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiviral properties of carnosine and related histidine-containing compounds against Influenza virus infection, focusing on their role in modulating neutrophil activity and reducing virus dissemination.
results_summary: The study found that carnosine and anserine stimulate respiratory burst in neutrophils, enhancing influenza virus destruction, and reduce apoptosis of human neutrophils, thereby limiting virus release and dissemination. These compounds demonstrated potential as a natural biological barrier against Influenza virus infection.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (specific population details not provided).
effective_dosage: Not specified (example given: 100 g of chicken breast contains 400 mg carnosine and 1020 mg anserine, but study dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of non-hydrolyzed carnosine formulations against reactive oxygen species, peroxynitrite damage, and viral injuries in influenza A (H1N1) infection.
results_summary: Carnosine demonstrated pharmacological intracellular correction of nitric oxide release, inhibition of cytotoxic NO-induced proinflammatory conditions, and attenuation of cytokine effects, suggesting potential in controlling influenza A virus replication and inflammation. Formulated non-hydrolyzed carnosine products showed promise in prevention but faced limitations due to enzymatic hydrolysis susceptibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (general implications for influenza A (H1N1) infection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-carnosine, as an adjunctive treatment, could improve executive dysfunction in individuals with chronic schizophrenia by targeting glutamatergic dysfunction.
results_summary: The L-carnosine group showed significant improvements in strategic efficiency and fewer perseverative errors on the strategic target detection test, as well as faster performance on non-reversal trials of the set-shifting test, but no significant differences were observed in reversal reaction times, errors, or other cognitive domains. Adverse events were more frequent in the carnosine group (30%) compared to placebo (14%), though laboratory indices remained normal.
population_specificity: Seventy-five symptomatically stable adults with chronic schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a topical cream containing urea 5%, arginine, and carnosine (UC) in improving skin hydration and reducing dryness in Type 2 diabetic patients compared to a glycerol-based emollient (EC).
results_summary: UC significantly improved skin hydration, reducing the Dryness Area Severity Index (DASI) score by 89% and achieving a higher Visual Analogue Score (VAS) for hydration compared to EC. The results were statistically significant, indicating UC's superior efficacy in alleviating skin dryness.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients aged 40-75 years.
effective_dosage: Twice-daily application of topical urea 5% with arginine and carnosine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of imidazole-containing dipeptides like carnosine to enhance α-crystallin chaperone activity and prevent or treat cataracts and other age-related eye diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine and related compounds can act as pharmacological chaperones, reducing oxidative stress and glycation-related damage, potentially delaying or reversing cataracts and other ocular conditions. Evidence from patents and experimental models supports their therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Human age-related eye diseases (cataracts, AMD, OCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic properties of Carnosine, particularly its antioxidant and metal ion-chelating effects, and the limitations posed by its homeostasis mechanisms.
results_summary: The study highlighted Carnosine's antioxidant and metal ion-chelating properties but noted that its therapeutic applications are limited by homeostasis mechanisms. It suggested that synthesized derivatives may offer future therapeutic potential for oxidative stress and metal ion dyshomeostasis-related pathologies.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal tissues mentioned, but human applicability implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review carnosine's role in neuroprotection against oxidative stress-driven disorders and its potential benefits in neurological conditions.
results_summary: The study found that carnosine exhibits multiple beneficial actions, including antioxidant, antiglycating, and neuroprotective effects, making it promising for treating oxidative stress-related neurological disorders. It also acts as a molecular chaperone and inducer of antioxidant systems.
population_specificity: Animal tissues and in vivo/in vitro models of cerebral damage (e.g., neurodegenerative disorders, hypoxia-ischemia injuries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate carnosine's role in inhibiting glycation and oxidative damage in skin aging and diabetes, and its potential to reverse AGE cross-links.
results_summary: Carnosine demonstrated significant transglycating and antioxidant activities, improved skin parameters, and reduced fine lines without reported side effects. Oral supplementation showed continuous and significant improvements in skin appearance compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 42 subjects in a randomized, double-blind, controlled study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (non-hydrolized carnosine in Can-C Plus® formulation).
study_duration: 3 months of supplementation followed by a 1-month supplement-free period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5 weeks of sprint training combined with different diets (vegetarian or mixed) could increase muscle carnosine content, carnosine synthase mRNA expression, and muscle buffering capacity.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of sprint training on muscle carnosine content or carnosine synthase mRNA expression, though there was a diet-specific interaction in soleus carnosine content (non-significant increase with mixed diet, decrease with vegetarian diet). Performance in repeated sprint ability improved with training, but no diet-related differences were observed.
population_specificity: Twenty omnivorous subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of carnosine and related compounds as mitochondria-targeted antioxidants to prevent ROS-induced damage in ocular tissues and manage cataracts.
results_summary: The study suggests carnosine and carcinine act as effective physiological antioxidants, protecting lipid membranes and aqueous environments, and proposes a patented ophthalmic composition (N-acetylcarnosine combined with mitochondria-targeted antioxidants) as a promising treatment for ROS-related ocular diseases, including cataracts.
population_specificity: Aging eye (general, no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of carnosine-based therapy (N-acetylcarnosine eye drops and oral nonhydrolyzed carnosine) to mitigate oxidative stress-induced damage in the trabecular meshwork and improve outcomes in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and cataracts.
results_summary: The study found that carnosine-based therapy, combined with conventional antiglaucoma treatments, significantly reduced intraocular pressure and improved outflow facility, while also minimizing oxidative stress-induced damage in the trabecular meshwork. Antioxidant pretreatment with carnosine also reduced POAG-typical changes like extracellular matrix accumulation and cell death.
population_specificity: Patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and ripe cataracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and mechanisms of N-acetylcarnosine and carcinine in treating sight-threatening eye disorders, including cataracts and oxidative stress-related damage.
results_summary: The study found that intraocular absorbed l-carnosine effectively prevented and reversed cataracts through multiple pharmacological mechanisms, while systemic absorption regulated neuronal functions related to vision. Carcinine was non-toxic to intraocular structures, reduced inflammation, and showed potential in treating proliferative vitreoretinopathy and protecting photoreceptor cells from oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Visually impaired individuals, including those with cataracts and other sight-threatening eye disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological and therapeutic activities of Carnosine and related imidazole-containing peptidomimetics, focusing on their pharmacological chaperone properties in treating protein-misfolding diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights Carnosine's potential as a pharmacological chaperone, demonstrating effectiveness in preventing misfolding of disease-causing proteins, particularly in neurodegenerative disorders, age-related macular degeneration, and cataracts. The abstract suggests Carnosine and related compounds possess diverse biological and pharmacological properties beneficial for human tissues.
population_specificity: Human tissues (specific population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of carnosine and its bioavailable forms against peroxynitrite damage and viral injuries in influenza A (H1N1) infection.
results_summary: Carnosine and its nonhydrolized forms showed protective effects by interacting with nitric oxide, inhibiting cytotoxic NO-induced proinflammatory conditions, and attenuating cytokine effects. These findings suggest carnosine may help control initial stages of influenza A infection and reduce tissue injuries.
population_specificity: 150 influenza A-infected patients and 140 healthy individuals, with additional in vitro studies on human lung epithelial cells and macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if carnosine-based therapy could protect telomere length and structure in smokers exposed to oxidative stress, potentially promoting healthy aging.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine may help maintain telomere length in smokers, reducing oxidative damage and inflammation linked to smoking, which could lower the risk of chronic diseases and support longevity.
population_specificity: Smokers, particularly those aged 25-44, at risk of oxidative stress-related telomere shortening.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the regulatory roles of imidazole-containing peptidomimetics like carnosine in skin homeostasis and their potential therapeutic applications for oxidative stress-related eye diseases.
results_summary: The study found that N-acetylcarnosine (NAC) and carcinine act as pharmacological chaperones, reducing oxidative stress and improving outcomes in eye diseases such as cataracts, glaucoma, and AMD. Patented formulations combining these compounds showed synergistic effects in ameliorating glycation stress-related phenotypes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on oxidative stress-related eye diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of molecular chaperone proteins, including imidazole-containing dipeptides like carnosine, in skin pathology, rejuvenation, wound healing, and stress response.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine and related dipeptides may play a protective role in skin stress response, hydration, and ageing by acting as molecular chaperones, improving protein hydration in photoaged skin, and potentially mitigating skin diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on skin pathology and ageing mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Carnosine, delivered via N-acetylcarnosine prodrug eye drops, could reduce telomere shortening in lens epithelial cells and improve visual functions in older adults and cataract patients.
results_summary: Carnosine significantly reduced telomere shortening in lens cells under oxidative stress and improved visual acuity and glare sensitivity in treated subjects compared to controls, which showed no improvement. The findings suggest potential therapeutic benefits for cataract prevention and management.
population_specificity: Older adult subjects and older subjects with cataracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of N-acetylcarnosine, L-carnosine, and carcinine on skin diseases, cosmetic skin lesions, and ocular conditions like cataracts and retinal degeneration.
results_summary: The study found that these compounds showed potential as treatments for age-related cataracts, macular degeneration, and diabetic ocular complications by interacting with proteins and mitigating oxidative stress. However, further investigation is needed before clinical application.
population_specificity: Patients with skin diseases, cosmetic skin lesions, or ocular conditions (e.g., cataracts, retinal degeneration, diabetic complications) and age-matched donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify objective dietary intake markers for meat, including Carnosine, to assess meat consumption in observational and intervention studies.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Carnosine as a potential marker for meat intake but does not provide specific results regarding its effects or efficacy as a biomarker.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Carnosine and related compounds in maintaining redox balance in the aging eye and treating cataracts, focusing on antioxidant, antiglycating, and chaperone-like activities.
results_summary: The study found that Carnosine and N-acetylcarnosine protected lens proteins from oxidative damage, enhanced visual acuity, and demonstrated synergistic effects with glutathione-boosting agents in reducing oxidative stress and cataract progression.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with or at risk of age-related eye diseases, particularly cataracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral formulations of nonhydrolized carnosine and carcinine could inhibit cumulative oxidative stress, inflammation, and telomere attrition associated with smoking.
results_summary: The study suggests that carnosine and carcinine formulations may effectively reduce oxidative stress and inflammation linked to smoking, potentially protecting against telomere shortening in white blood cells. Longitudinal clinical data supported the hypothesis that telomere length could predict survival and treatment needs in smokers.
population_specificity: Elderly and clinical population groups, particularly smokers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a formula containing carnosine and other antioxidants could reduce oxidative stress and homocysteine levels in patients with moderate probable Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that the formula (including carnosine) significantly decreased oxidative stress and homocysteine levels, increased glutathione in erythrocytes, and reduced sickle erythrocytes in treated patients. Some cognitive improvements were also noted in the group receiving the formula alongside donepezil.
population_specificity: 52 patients (21 males, 31 females) with moderate probable Alzheimer's disease, already treated with donepezil.
effective_dosage: Low doses (specific amounts not detailed), administered once daily in a two-phase ampoule.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of carnosine supplementation on salivary flow characteristics in healthy subjects and those with oral cavity pathologies.
results_summary: The study compared salivary flow and oral microbiome characteristics before and after 7 days of carnosine supplementation, expecting to clarify its mechanism of action, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (n=20) and subjects with common oral cavity pathologies (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polaprezinc (zinc L-carnosine) could prevent radiochemotherapy-induced oral mucositis, pain, xerostomia, and taste disturbance in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: Polaprezinc significantly reduced the incidence of mucositis, pain, xerostomia, and taste disturbance compared to the control group, decreased analgesic use, and improved food intake without affecting tumor response rates.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiochemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how carnosine, as a dietary antioxidant, activates hormetic pathways and vitagenes to enhance defensive systems involved in stress resistance and longevity.
results_summary: The study suggests carnosine exhibits neuroprotective properties by activating vitagenes and hormetic pathways, potentially improving stress resistance and longevity processes. However, specific clinical outcomes or mechanistic details are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses general mechanisms and animal models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether anserine/carnosine supplementation (ACS) suppresses chemokine levels in elderly people.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide sufficient information to summarize the study's findings regarding Carnosine's effects.
population_specificity: Sixty healthy elderly volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Essence of Chicken (EC) on cognitive function, particularly working memory, through a meta-analysis of existing studies.
results_summary: Daily EC intake showed favorable effects on cognitive function, especially in the working memory domain, with statistically significant results. The findings were robust across sensitivity and subgroup analyses, suggesting potential benefits for mental processing in healthy individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy population (794 subjects pooled from 8 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation increases muscle carnosine content in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in carnosine content in the gastrocnemius or soleus muscles after 12 weeks of creatine supplementation compared to placebo. The researchers concluded that creatine does not augment muscle carnosine levels in this population.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological potential of carotenoids, particularly lutein, zeaxanthin, and astaxanthin, in treating ocular disorders like AMD and DR, focusing on their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: The study found that nano-formulated carotenoids improve bioavailability, cellular absorption, and biostability, making them superior to conventional carotenoids for treating eye diseases. Some clinical studies support their beneficial effects in countering inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Individuals with vision-endangering eye diseases, such as AMD and DR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic and antioxidant effects of carotenoid extracts from pumpkin pulp on neuroblastoma cells and characterize their carotenoid profiles.
results_summary: Pumpkin carotenoid extracts showed cytotoxic effects against SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells, particularly Butternut and Mantovana extracts at specific concentrations, and demonstrated antioxidant activity in vitro. The extracts primarily contained β-carotene and esterified hydroxy- and epoxy-carotenoids, which helped differentiate species.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Butternut extract at 100 μM (53.69 μg/mL), Mantovana extract at 50 μM (26.84 μg/mL)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining carnosine with anserine could circumvent degradation by serum carnosinase-1 and enhance muscle performance during high-intensity exercise.
results_summary: The study found that combining carnosine and anserine improved bioavailability and enhanced performance during a high-intensity cycling test, suggesting a potential ergogenic effect.
population_specificity: Five subjects in bioavailability testing; participants in two double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover studies (specific number not stated).
effective_dosage: 25 mg/kg anserine alone or combined with 25 mg/kg carnosine (bioavailability); 20 mg/kg each of anserine and carnosine (performance study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the carotenoid content, provitamin A activity, and stability of carotenoid-rich emulsions derived from peach palm fruit peel.
results_summary: The red variety of peach palm peel had higher carotenoid and phenolic content, with β-carotene and γ-carotene as major compounds. An optimized carotenoid-rich emulsion showed stability for 35 days, with potential as a biofunctional food additive.
population_specificity: Peach palm fruit peel (Bactris gasipaes) byproduct.
effective_dosage: Optimized emulsion contained 67.61 μg/g total carotenoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether anserine/carnosine supplementation (ACS) could preserve cognitive function in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that ACS significantly preserved delayed recall verbal memory, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and suppressed age-related decline in brain blood flow in the posterior cingulate cortex.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly volunteers aged 60-78 years.
effective_dosage: 1.0 g of an anserine/carnosine (3:1) formula daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of carotenoids as alternative treatments for metabolic syndrome (MetS) by examining their biological activities, sources, extraction methods, and encapsulation approaches to prevent degradation.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids exhibit multiple beneficial effects for MetS, including reducing serum triglycerides, promoting insulin response, inhibiting adipogenesis, and downregulating angiotensin-converting enzyme activity, but they are sensitive to environmental factors like pH, light, and temperature. Encapsulation was proposed as a method to enhance stability and biological performance.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and the elderly affected by metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which calcium chloride (CaCl2) treatment suppresses carotenoid degradation in shredded carrots and its impact on carotenoid biosynthesis and degradation enzymes.
results_summary: CaCl2 treatment promoted carotenoid biosynthesis by enhancing phytoene synthase (PSY) activity and suppressed degradation by inhibiting carotenoid cleavage dioxygenase (CCD) activity, maintaining higher levels of key carotenoids. EGTA treatment had the opposite effect, increasing carotenoid degradation. CaCl2's effect was mediated through DcCAMTA4, which suppressed CCD gene expression.
population_specificity: Shredded carrots (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether egg yolk phospholipids (EPL) could improve the thermal-oxidative stability of chili oil and protect carotenoids and capsaicinoids during frying.
results_summary: The study found that EPL-treated samples retained higher concentrations of carotenoids and capsaicinoids compared to control samples when fried at 150°C, suggesting EPL may act as an antioxidant during frying.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using chili oil)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of carotenoids in mitigating mitochondrial dysfunction, focusing on their antioxidant properties and potential therapeutic applications for age-related diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that carotenoids may ameliorate mitochondrial dysfunction by reducing oxidative stress and ROS accumulation, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for age-related diseases like Alzheimer's and metabolic disorders. However, the exact mechanisms and efficacy of carotenoids in this context are not fully understood.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on age-related diseases and metabolic disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of red fruit (rich in carotenoids) as a depigmentation agent for managing melasma.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids in red fruit can block melanogenesis through PKA, ERK, and AKT signaling pathways, reducing hyperpigmentation and promoting skin brightening.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human nutrition context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of pasteurization temperature and storage time on the retention of carotenoids (lycopene and β-carotene) and other antioxidants in salmorejo.
results_summary: Carotenoids showed good retention levels during shelf life under refrigeration, especially when pasteurized at 80°C, though vitamin C degraded more quickly. Thermal treatment improved carotenoid content with minor losses of thermolabile vitamin C.
population_specificity: Salmorejo (a tomato-oil puree) as a food product.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on food processing, not supplementation).
study_duration: Storage time assessed up to 5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if skin carotenoid status (SCS) could serve as a valid biomarker for tracking changes in carotenoid intake through a whole-diet intervention.
results_summary: The high-carotenoid group showed a faster and greater increase in SCS compared to the control group, with baseline SCS positively correlating with carotenoid intake, fruit and vegetable intake, and serum carotenoid concentrations.
population_specificity: 80 healthy participants aged 20 to 49 years without underlying diseases.
effective_dosage: High-carotenoid diet (21 mg total carotenoids/2000 kcal) vs. control diet (13.6 mg total carotenoids/2000 kcal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how legume protein fibrils, formed under varying salt concentrations, affect the encapsulation, stability, and bioaccessibility of liposoluble carotenoids in high internal phase emulsions (HIPEs).
results_summary: The study found that HIPEs stabilized by high-salt-concentration-induced legume protein fibrils improved carotenoid encapsulation, stability against heat/UV/iron ions, and bioaccessibility during simulated GI digestion. These HIPEs also demonstrated in vivo nutritional benefits for mitigating colitis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo study, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (salt concentrations: 0-300 mM for fibril preparation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate carotenoid absorption and status in patients with familial hypobetalipoproteinemias (FHBL-SD1 and FHBL-SD3) to determine if carotenoid supplementation could address deficiencies and potentially improve visual function.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in carotenoid absorption (ranging from -65.4% to -96.7%) in FHBL patient models and confirmed severe carotenoid deficiencies in patient plasma levels (-89% to -98% compared to controls), suggesting potential clinical utility for supplementation to prevent visual impairment.
population_specificity: Patients with familial hypobetalipoproteinemias (FHBL-SD1 and FHBL-SD3) and control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological activity of a carotenoids mixture (MC) from starfish Patiria pectinifera, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, anti-allergic, and cancer-preventive properties.
results_summary: The study found that MC exhibited significant anti-inflammatory, anti-allergic, and cancer-preventive effects, reducing papilloma incidence by 1.5 times in skin carcinogenesis and improving allergic contact dermatitis by 80%. It also normalized cytokine profiles and antioxidant defense systems without toxicity at 500 mg/kg.
population_specificity: Animal models (inflammatory diseases: skin carcinogenesis, allergic contact dermatitis, systemic inflammation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize phytoene accumulation in Chlorella sorokiniana using norflurazon and evaluate the effectiveness of green solvents for carotenoid extraction.
results_summary: The study found that norflurazon (1 µg/mL) effectively blocked the carotenoid pathway, increasing phytoene accumulation. Milling pre-treatment improved carotenoid recovery, and 2-methyloxolane outperformed other solvents in extraction efficiency.
population_specificity: Chlorella sorokiniana (microalgae)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to revisit the physiological functions of six major carotenoids as biological antioxidants, focusing on their roles in health promotion and disease prevention.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids exhibit antioxidant activity, with specific benefits such as protecting macular cells (lutein and zeaxanthin), reducing oxidative damage in the testis (lycopene), and enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity (β-carotene metabolites). However, excessive accumulation may have prooxidant effects.
population_specificity: Humans (general, with specific mentions of macular cells and testis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of saffron carotenoids (Crocin and Crocetin) on depression and anxiety in rats, focusing on their molecular mechanisms, including serotonin and corticosterone levels and hippocampal signaling pathways.
results_summary: Crocin and Crocetin improved depression and anxiety in rats, increased serum serotonin, reduced corticosterone, and modulated hippocampal signaling proteins (e.g., CREB, BDNF). Bioinformatics and patch-clamp data suggested interactions with serotonin transporters and NMDA receptors, similar to Fluoxetine.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to unpredictable chronic mild stress (UCMS) to induce depression and anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of carotenoids on gut microbiota, gut barrier function, and inflammation in healthy animals.
results_summary: Carotenoids promoted beneficial gut bacteria, improved gut barrier integrity, increased mucin expression, enhanced nutrient absorption, and modulated inflammatory cytokines, though effects varied by carotenoid type.
population_specificity: Healthy animals (mice, rats, pigs, chicks, drosophila, fish, and shrimp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiproliferative, antioxidant, and proapoptotic properties of carotenoids from Sea buckthorn berries extract (LSBE) in breast cancer cell lines.
results_summary: LSBE inhibited breast cancer cell proliferation (mean IC50 of 16 µM), demonstrated strong antioxidant activity, and induced significant apoptosis (80.29% in T47D and 40.6% in BT-549 cells).
population_specificity: Two breast cancer cell lines (T47D: ER+, PR+, HER2-; BT-549: ER-, PR-, HER2-).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of carotenoids (β-carotene, lutein, astaxanthin, fucoxanthin) in reducing secondary complications induced by NSAIDs, particularly aspirin, during inflammation treatment.
results_summary: Carotenoids, especially fucoxanthin combined with aspirin, significantly reduced oxidative stress, pro-inflammatory mediators, and cytokines, while also inhibiting apoptosis and lowering intracellular ROS generation. The combination showed greater efficacy than carotenoids or aspirin alone.
population_specificity: Raw 264.7, U937, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Raman spectroscopy could identify carotenoids as potential biomarkers for diagnosing and monitoring multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that Raman spectroscopy, combined with chemometric analysis, identified lipid and carotenoid molecules as useful biomarkers for MS diagnosis and treatment monitoring. The results suggest this method could provide a rapid and minimally invasive diagnostic tool.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro cytotoxic effect of Haloferax mediterranei bacterioruberin-rich carotenoid extracts (BRCE) on breast cancer (BC) cell lines, including triple-negative subtypes, and a healthy mammary epithelium cell line.
results_summary: BRCE selectively affected BC cells (SI > 1, p < 0.005), reducing their population to 11.7-64.6% of the control at 100 µg/ml after 30 hours. Triple-negative cells (MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-468) showed significant sensitivity, with IC50 values of 51.8 µg/ml and 63.9 µg/ml, respectively, and reduced cell size.
population_specificity: Six BC cell lines representing intrinsic phenotypes and a healthy mammary epithelium cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of carotenoid nano-drug delivery systems for improving the treatment of Alzheimer's disease by addressing solubility, stability, and bioavailability issues.
results_summary: The study found that various carotenoid nano-drug delivery systems (polymer, lipid, inorganic, and hybrid) improved solubility, stability, permeability, and bioavailability, leading to beneficial therapeutic effects on Alzheimer's disease. However, specific efficacy data or clinical outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on Alzheimer's disease treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential roles of carotenoids in preventing or ameliorating diabetes-related complications based on preclinical animal studies and human intervention trials.
results_summary: Carotenoids showed antidiabetic potential in in vitro and in vivo models, likely through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory mechanisms, though clinical evidence remains scarce.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal models and human intervention trials (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the production, extraction, purification, and commercialization of carotenoids from microalgae, focusing on their potential biotechnological applications and health benefits.
results_summary: The study highlights that carotenoids, particularly fucoxanthin, have significant antioxidant properties and potential benefits for preventing and treating lifestyle-related diseases. Microalgae like Chlorella, Dunaliella, and Phaeodactylum tricornutum are promising sources of these valuable pigments.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies on microalgae and cyanobacteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare modern, non-invasive methods (skin measurements and app-based dietary records) with conventional methods (plasma status and handwritten dietary records) for assessing dietary carotenoid intake.
results_summary: The study found that app-based intake data and skin measurements correlated well with plasma levels of α-carotene, β-carotene, and total carotenoids, but showed weak or no correlation with lutein/zeaxanthin, β-cryptoxanthin, and lycopene. Skin measurements and the app-based method were deemed convenient alternatives to blood sampling for estimating fruit and vegetable consumption.
population_specificity: 21 healthy participants aged 50-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the mechanism of carotenoids in the AMPK pathway in adipose tissue and their role in regulating adipogenesis, particularly in the context of high-fat diet-induced complications.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids can activate the AMPK signaling pathway, leading to improved lipid metabolism, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and inhibition of adipogenesis. Different carotenoids were noted to upregulate transcriptional factors, induce white adipose tissue browning, and enhance adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on obesity and high-fat diet-induced metabolic dysregulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connection between oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and neurodegenerative disorders, and to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties of carotenoids for managing these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids exhibit significant anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, which may help prevent and treat neurodegenerative disorders by reducing oxidative stress and chronic inflammation. A strong correlation was noted between carotenoid levels and the avoidance of such ailments.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on neurodegenerative disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sensitivity of pressure-mediated reflection spectroscopy (RS) to detect changes in skin carotenoids in response to increasing carotenoid intake.
results_summary: The study found a correlation between skin and plasma carotenoids (r = 0.65). Skin carotenoid levels increased significantly with higher intake levels, detectable as early as week 1 for the HIGH group, week 2 for the MED group, and week 3 for the LOW group. Group differences were detectable with a minimum intake of 23.9 mg of carotenoids.
population_specificity: Nonobese adults (mean age ~30-33 years, mean BMI ~24-26 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 13.1 mg (LOW), 23.9 mg (MED), 31.0 mg (HIGH) daily via commercial vegetable juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if biofeedback and dietary intervention (fruit juice intake) could improve cutaneous carotenoid concentrations as a biomarker for antioxidant status.
results_summary: Participants showed increasing carotenoid levels over time, with biofeedback alone and combined with fruit juice intake leading to improvements in skin carotenoid values. The study suggests biofeedback may be an effective method for enhancing antioxidant status.
population_specificity: 44 adults
effective_dosage: Not specified (fruit juice intake mentioned but no dosage details)
study_duration: Not specified (phases described but no exact duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of thermal processing on carotenoid content and antioxidant activities in different stages of M. charantia fruit.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoid content decreased with increasing temperature during thermal processing, while antioxidant activities increased, particularly in mature yellow fruit (S3). The 90 °C treatment showed the highest increase in antioxidant activity, with a 6.8-fold higher level in S3 compared to nonthermal treatment.
population_specificity: M. charantia fruit at different maturity stages (immature green, mature green, and mature yellow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the lipid and carotenoid coproduction capability of the novel green alga Coelastrella sp. D3-1 under various cultivation conditions and assess its potential as a biorefinery material.
results_summary: The study found that Coelastrella sp. D3-1 produced significant amounts of carotenoids (38.5% of DCW), including echinenone, canthaxanthin, and astaxanthin, under optimal conditions within 5-6 days. The extracts also demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory abilities, suggesting potential biorefinery applications.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on algal cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biomedical properties of carotenoids produced from yeast using vegetable waste, focusing on their antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anti-breast cancer activities, particularly against triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
results_summary: The carotenoid extract, composed of β-carotene, torulene, and torularhodin, showed significant antioxidant, antimicrobial, and anti-breast cancer activities in vitro, with better efficacy in TNBC cells than ER+PR+ cells. In silico studies predicted good binding with breast cancer-specific molecular targets and favorable drug-likeness properties with low toxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro breast cancer cells (TNBC and ER+PR+ subtypes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of carotenoids in carrot extracts on the growth inhibition of various Candida species, including Candida albicans, Candida glabrata, Candida parapsilosis, and Candida tropicalis.
results_summary: The study found that carrot extract at 500 mg/ml showed the highest growth inhibition for C. glabrata and C. tropicalis. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) was 62.5 mg/ml for C. albicans, C. glabrata, and C. parapsilosis, and 125 mg/ml for C. tropicalis, while the minimum fungicidal concentration (MFC) was 125 mg/ml for the former three and 250 mg/ml for C. tropicalis.
population_specificity: Candida species (C. albicans, C. glabrata, C. parapsilosis, C. tropicalis) in vitro.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/ml (highest tested concentration), MIC/MFC ranged from 62.5 mg/ml to 250 mg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular mechanism by which blue light promotes carotenoid biosynthesis in microalgae, focusing on the role of cryptochrome genes.
results_summary: The study found that cryptochrome genes (HpCRY4 and PtCPF1) were upregulated under blue light, correlating with increased astaxanthin and fucoxanthin production. Heterologous expression and gene knockout experiments confirmed their role in regulating carotenoid biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Microalgae species (Haematococcus pluvialis and Phaeodactylum tricornutum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between blood carotenoid concentrations, skin AGEs levels, and severe erectile dysfunction (ED) in men.
results_summary: Higher skin AGEs levels and lower blood carotenoid concentrations (lutein, zeaxanthin, β-cryptoxanthin, α-carotene, β-carotene, total lycopene, and cis-lycopenes) were significantly associated with severe ED. Serum zeaxanthin levels were negatively correlated with skin AGEs levels, suggesting a potential protective role.
population_specificity: 335 community-dwelling men with ED (median age 57 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavonoids and carotenoids from certain plants could prevent UV-induced skin damage.
results_summary: The review found consistent positive effects of carotenoid-containing plant extracts on UV-induced skin damage across in vitro, animal, and human studies, suggesting potential benefits in preventing photoaging and skin cancers.
population_specificity: In vitro, animal, and human studies (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify natural carotenoids capable of blocking TNF-α-hTNFR1 interaction to potentially mitigate cytokine storms in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Among 125 carotenoids screened, Sorgomol, Strigol, and Orobanchol showed the highest binding affinity and stability with TNF-α, with Sorgomol exhibiting the strongest inhibitory potential based on molecular dynamics simulations.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (in silico study, no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of different debittering methods on the preservation of carotenoids and other bioactive compounds in Lupinus albus seeds.
results_summary: Debittering with citric acid or NaCl preserved higher concentrations of carotenoids (10.9-25.1 mg/kg DM) compared to methods involving ultrasound, which caused significant losses. The study found that shorter treatment times minimized leaching of antioxidant compounds.
population_specificity: Lupinus albus seeds (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on debittering methods).
study_duration: Not specified (time of debittering treatment not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic applications of microalgae-derived carotenoids and discuss optimization strategies for their production.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that microalgae-derived carotenoids have significant metabolic roles and therapeutic potential for conditions like cancer and cardiovascular diseases, but commercial production remains limited. It also mentions biotechnological approaches to improve carotenoid yields.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of microalgae-derived carotenoids)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review existing evidence on the neuroprotective potential of carotenoids in Alzheimer's disease (AD) prevention and symptom alleviation.
results_summary: The review found that carotenoids show promise in preclinical studies for neuroprotection, but high-quality randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are lacking to confirm their efficacy in AD patients. Specific carotenoids like astaxanthin, fucoxanthin, macular carotenoids, and crocin were highlighted as needing further research.
population_specificity: Aging population with or at risk of Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential of dietary carotenoids in treating respiratory diseases and identify candidates for novel therapeutic development.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids have potent health-promoting properties linked to reducing chronic respiratory diseases like COPD, lung cancer, and asthma, with potential to alter pathogenic pathways in inflammatory respiratory diseases.
population_specificity: General population relying on dietary carotenoids for respiratory health (no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of microalgal carotenoids as adjuvants in antimelanoma therapy, focusing on their safety, tolerability, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that microalgal carotenoids (e.g., fucoxanthin, astaxanthin, zeaxanthin) inhibited melanoma cell proliferation, migration, and invasion, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, and restored sensitivity to conventional chemotherapy. These effects were linked to modulation of MAPK, NF-ĸB pathways, MMP, and apoptotic factors.
population_specificity: Melanoma cell lines (in vitro and in vivo experimental models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exogenous melatonin (MLT) and light induction on carotenoid accumulation in Dunaliella bardawil.
results_summary: Exogenous MLT alone inhibited growth and pigment accumulation in Dunaliella bardawil, but combined with light induction, it significantly increased zeaxanthin and other carotenoid levels, with 300 μg/mL MLT showing the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Dunaliella bardawil microalgae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carotenoids from Cordyceps militaris (CMCT) could protect human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19) from oxidative damage and apoptosis, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: CMCT protected ARPE-19 cells from H2O2-induced oxidative damage and apoptosis by upregulating Bcl-2, reducing Bax and cleaved caspase-3 expression, lowering ROS and NOX1 levels, and restoring antioxidant enzyme activity (CAT, SOD, GSH) via Nrf2 activation.
population_specificity: Human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if scientific evidence supports carotenoid supplementation for alleviating cancer-related symptoms, particularly neuropathic pain and cachexia, in advanced-stage cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests carotenoids have promising antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties, potentially beneficial for symptom relief in palliative care, but does not provide specific study results.
population_specificity: Advanced-stage cancer patients receiving palliative care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carotenoid accumulation in papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) patients is linked to retinoic acid (RA) biosynthesis, RA-related pathway activation, or antioxidant functions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall carotenoid content between PTC and healthy tissues, but PTCs showed downregulated RA-related pathways and increased oxidative stress, possibly due to prooxidant effects of high carotenoid levels. High carotenoid content in PTCs also correlated with tryptophan metabolism.
population_specificity: Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) patients, including analysis of 474 PTC cases from the Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) project.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on carotenoid metabolism in Euglena, focusing on distribution, biosynthesis, accumulation under stress, and potential applications in therapy and industries.
results_summary: Carotenoids exhibit superior photoprotective and antioxidant properties, reducing risks of cancers, cardiovascular diseases, and eye conditions. Their antioxidant mechanisms include quenching free radicals and hindering lipid peroxidation, with potential applications in therapy, cosmetics, food, and animal feed.
population_specificity: Microalgae (Euglena) and higher plants, with implications for human dietary benefits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of postharvest pulsed light (PL) treatments of different spectral ranges on carotenoid concentration and quality attributes in tomatoes.
results_summary: PL treatments, particularly VIS + NIR light, accelerated the accumulation of total carotenoids (31%) and lycopene (35%) in tomatoes by day 5 post-treatment without affecting quality attributes, while UV-light exposure did not enhance carotenoid concentrations.
population_specificity: Tomato fruits postharvest.
effective_dosage: Doses of wide-spectrum light (180-1100 nm), full-spectrum without UV-C (305-1100 nm), and VIS + NIR (400-1100 nm).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted just after treatments and at 1, 5, and 10 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the shared-pathway hypothesis, which proposes a biochemical link between ketocarotenoid metabolism and mitochondrial function.
results_summary: The study found that DNP-treated copepods showed increased respiration and higher ketocarotenoid accumulation, supporting the hypothesis that ketocarotenoid and mitochondrial metabolism are interconnected. The association between ketocarotenoid concentration and metabolic rate was strongest in DNP-treated copepods.
population_specificity: Tigriopus californicus copepods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different LED light combinations (blue and white, red and white, or white alone) affect carotenoid levels and biosynthesis in pak choi sprouts.
results_summary: Blue and white LEDs increased carotenoid levels by ~15% compared to white LEDs alone, while red and white LEDs reduced them. Transcript levels of carotenoid metabolism-related genes and phytoene accumulation were enhanced under blue and white LEDs, suggesting up-regulation of the carotenoid biosynthetic pathway.
population_specificity: Pak choi (Brassica rapa ssp. chinensis 'Black Behi') sprouts

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regulatory roles of carotenoid metabolism genes under UV-B irradiation and their impact on carotenoid and apocarotenoid balance in peaches.
results_summary: UV-B irradiation increased carotenoid content by 30% after 6 hours and delayed the decline of lutein and β-carotene during storage. The transcript levels of key genes (PpPSY, PpLCY-B, PpLCY-E, and PpCCD4) were significantly altered, affecting the metabolic balance between carotenoids and apocarotenoids.
population_specificity: Peach fruit (higher plants)
study_duration: 6 hours of UV-B irradiation, with observations up to 48 hours of storage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the cytotoxic effects of crocins (CRCs) and dimethylcrocetin (DMCRT) on glioblastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines, focusing on apoptosis and cell survival pathways.
results_summary: Both CRCs and DMCRT demonstrated dose- and time-dependent cytotoxicity against glioblastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines, inducing apoptosis via upregulation of BAX and BID and downregulation of MYCN, BCL-2, SOD1, and GSTM1. The study suggests potential anticancer properties of saffron carotenoids.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: CRCs: 22.85 to 0.18 mg/mL; DMCRT: 11.43 to 0.09 mg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of carotenoids in treating blood cancers by examining their mechanisms and signaling pathways.
results_summary: Carotenoids demonstrated efficacy in inducing apoptosis and inhibiting cancer cell proliferation through multiple pathways, including AMPK activation, autophagy markers, and modulation of reactive oxygen species. The abstract highlights their potential as a versatile phytochemical for blood cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Blood cancer (hematological malignancies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of food-derived carotenoids, particularly crocin, as alternative therapeutics and dietary supplements for the prophylaxis and treatment of SARS-CoV-2 through in silico screening and molecular docking.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids, especially crocin, exhibited strong binding affinities to multiple SARS-CoV-2 target proteins, suggesting potential inhibitory effects. Molecular dynamics simulations confirmed the stability of crocin complexes with these targets, supporting its potential as a therapeutic candidate.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of phosphatidylcholine from eggs versus a choline bitartrate supplement on plasma carotenoids (lutein and zeaxanthin) in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Egg intake significantly increased plasma lutein and zeaxanthin levels compared to baseline or choline bitartrate supplementation, suggesting potential protective effects against oxidative stress in metabolic syndrome. No significant changes in TMAO levels or gut microbiota diversity were observed between treatments.
population_specificity: 23 subjects with metabolic syndrome
effective_dosage: Three eggs per day (providing 400 mg/day of choline equivalent)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of marine carotenoids in enhancing neuroplasticity and their potential therapeutic effects on central nervous system disorders.
results_summary: The study found that marine carotenoids exhibit potent antioxidant properties, inhibit oxidative stress and neuroinflammation, and promote synaptogenesis and neurogenesis, suggesting neuroprotective activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on CNS disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the links between dietary carotenoids and head and neck cancer (HNC), focusing on their potential anticancer effects and chemopreventive properties.
results_summary: The study found strong epidemiological associations between dietary carotenoids and reduced HNC risk, with evidence suggesting positive effects on carcinogenesis stages, oxidative stress regulation, apoptosis, and other cellular mechanisms. Limited preclinical and clinical research supports the potential of carotenoids as chemotherapeutic and chemopreventive agents.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients and general population (epidemiological focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the composition of carotenoids in citrus fruits and their associated health benefits, particularly in reducing the risk of metabolic syndrome-related diseases.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids in citrus fruits, along with other bioactive compounds, contribute to reduced risks of neurodegenerative diseases, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cancer. Mechanistic, observational, and intervention studies supported these health benefits.
population_specificity: General population (not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of tomato pomace (a source of carotenoids) on digestive enzymes, immune response, antioxidant status, and carotenoid deposition in egg yolks of Japanese quail breeders.
results_summary: Tomato pomace supplementation improved immune response, antioxidant status, digestive enzymes, and carotenoid (lycopene) deposition in egg yolks, while also enhancing egg weight, egg mass, and hatchability. The 6% inclusion level showed the most significant benefits.
population_specificity: Mature 8-week-old Japanese quail breeders (100 females and 50 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for simultaneously determining fat-soluble vitamins and carotenoids in human serum to diagnose malnutrition and guide interventions.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the SAIL-based DLLME method coupled with HPLC effectively enriched and detected carotenoids and fat-soluble vitamins in human serum, with high accuracy (recoveries 82.4-114.1%) and precision (intra-day RSD 2.76-12.63%, inter-day RSD 4.01-13.54%). The method showed superior enrichment factors (4-26 times) compared to traditional LLE.
population_specificity: Human serum samples (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between carotenoid intake and depressive symptoms in middle-aged Korean females and explore potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids, particularly lycopene and zeaxanthin, were negatively associated with depressive symptoms. In silico analysis suggested carotenoids may allosterically activate brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), indicating potential therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Middle-aged Korean females

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the relationship between oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and neurodegenerative disorders, and to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of carotenoids in managing these disorders.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids exhibit significant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, which may help prevent and treat neurodegenerative disorders by mitigating oxidative stress and chronic inflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of neurodegenerative disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in carotenoid isomerization methods and their impact on processing efficiency, bioavailability, and biological activity.
results_summary: The study found that Z-isomerization of carotenoids improves their solubility, crystallinity, processing efficiency, and bioavailability, with potential benefits for biological activity. Various isomerization methods, including thermal treatment and light irradiation, were highlighted as effective.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of carotenoid research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the structure, properties, and mechanisms by which carotenoids act as chemopreventative agents against cancer.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids, such as β-carotene, α-carotene, lycopene, β-cryptoxanthin, zeaxanthin, and lutein, demonstrate anticarcinogenic properties and may play a role in preventing oncogenesis for various cancers. The review highlights the potential of carotenoids in disease prevention, particularly for cancer.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human serum carotenoid levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the protective effect of dietary carotenoids, polyphenols, and estradiol on dermal fibroblasts under oxidative stress induced by H2O2.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with tomato and rosemary extracts (rich in carotenoids and polyphenols) and estradiol reversed oxidative stress effects, reducing intracellular ROS levels and increasing ARE/Nrf2 activity, thereby protecting dermal fibroblasts from damage.
population_specificity: Human dermal fibroblasts (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant interactions between carotenoids (lycopene, lutein) and flavonoids (quercetin, luteolin) and their effects on cellular uptake, ROS scavenging, and antioxidant enzyme activities.
results_summary: Combinations of carotenoids with flavonoids, particularly lycopene and quercetin at a 1:5 ratio, showed stronger antioxidant activity, enhanced cellular uptake of carotenoids, and increased expression of carotenoid transporters. Flavonoids modulated carotenoid effects on transporter expression, with synergistic groups showing improved antioxidant outcomes.
population_specificity: HUVEC, Caco-2, and L-02 cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Total concentration of 8 μM (specific ratios varied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bioavailability and safety of carotenoids, specifically fucoxanthin (FX), from Phaeodactylum tricornutum (PT) in healthy individuals.
results_summary: PT intake led to the uptake of FX, which was metabolized to fucoxanthinol (FXOH) and amarouciaxanthin A (AxA), demonstrating bioavailability. No relevant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 22 healthy individuals (with an additional experiment involving 9 individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the anti-inflammatory activities of eight different carotenoids against inflammation induced by various stimuli, including pathogen-associated molecular patterns, proinflammatory cytokines, degenerated proteins, and chemical irritants.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids exhibited characteristic anti-inflammatory activities, with unsubstituted β-ring and C8-keto structures being crucial for their inhibitory effects on inflammatory pathways. β-carotene and echinenone increased intracellular retinoid levels in monocytes, which showed similar anti-inflammatory activities.
population_specificity: Monocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photoprotective effects of carotenoid-rich persimmon extract (PEC) against UV-induced cell damage in HaCaT keratinocytes and its potential as a functional skincare ingredient.
results_summary: PEC reduced UV-induced intracellular ROS production in HaCaT cells, demonstrated photoprotective and regenerative effects, and enhanced skin microbiome adhesion while inhibiting pathogen adhesion, with no observed cytotoxicity at tested concentrations.
population_specificity: HaCaT keratinocyte cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of high pressure processing (HPP) on the extractability, bioaccessibility, and antioxidant capacity of carotenoids in kale.
results_summary: The study found that higher pressures and extended holding times during HPP slightly decreased carotenoid extractability but increased bioaccessibility and antioxidant capacity in kale. The results suggest matrix-dependent effects during digestion.
population_specificity: Kale (food matrix)
effective_dosage: Pressure levels (200-600 MPa) and holding times (5-40 min)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current knowledge on the anti-inflammatory and anticancer activities of microalgal carotenoids, both in vitro and in vivo, and assess their potential for human use in preventing and treating inflammatory diseases and cancer.
results_summary: The review highlights that microalgal carotenoids exhibit significant anti-inflammatory and anticancer activities in preclinical studies, with potential benefits for human health, though human studies are still in early stages.
population_specificity: Not specified (includes in vitro, in vivo, and human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the roles of vitamin A and carotenoids in breast cancer prevention and treatment, including their association with genetic variations and epidemiological evidence.
results_summary: The study suggests that vitamin A and carotenoids may have protective roles against breast cancer development and exhibit potential as therapeutic agents, though clinical application remains limited. Epidemiological evidence supports their association with reduced breast cancer risk.
population_specificity: Women, particularly in the context of breast cancer risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the drug-likeness and cholinesterase inhibitory potential of specific carotenoids (beta-carotenoids, lutein, neoxanthin, and viola-xanthine) from Lycopersicon esculentum varieties for treating Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Neoxanthin was identified as the safest and most effective cholinesterase inhibitor with high binding affinity and stability in a biological environment, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic candidate for Alzheimer's disease. Other carotenoids also showed promise but were less effective compared to neoxanthin.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or computational study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best cooking methods for vegetables to maintain minerals (potassium and sodium) and carotenoids.
results_summary: The study found that heat treatment generally improves carotenoid accessibility. Organic carrots had higher carotenoid concentrations in raw form, while conventional cultivation yielded higher levels in zucchini and broccoli.
population_specificity: Broccoli, carrots, and zucchini (organic and conventionally grown).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the neuroprotective potential of xanthophyll carotenoids (lutein, zeaxanthin, and meso-zeaxanthin) on retinal neurodegeneration as an adjunctive nutraceutical strategy for managing AMD.
results_summary: Greater dietary consumption of carotenoids was associated with enhanced risk reduction against late AMD, and higher macular pigment concentrations improved visual function in AMD patients. Carotenoid therapies showed synergistic protection in the neurosensory retina, potentially serving as adjunctive therapy for AMD, though benefits varied by disease stage.
population_specificity: Older adults with or at risk of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with xanthophyll carotenoids (lutein and zeaxanthin) could regenerate antioxidant capacity in diabetic patients and improve retinal health and visual function.
results_summary: Lutein and zeaxanthin showed significant protection against capillary cell degeneration and hyperglycemia-induced retinal vascular changes. Early interventional trials indicated improved serum and macular pigment levels alongside visual performance benefits, suggesting therapeutic potential for diabetic retinopathy management.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic retinopathy, particularly type 2 or poorly managed type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-angiogenic and anti-proliferative effects of carotenoids from Spondias mombin via VEGFR-2 kinase domain inhibition in a DMBA-induced breast carcinoma model.
results_summary: Carotenoid isolates significantly downregulated VEGF, VEGFR, EGFR, HIF-1, and MMP-2 mRNAs while upregulating CHD-1 mRNA, demonstrating anti-angiogenic and anti-proliferative effects. Molecular docking confirmed strong binding of specific carotenoids to the ATP binding site of VEGFR-2.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with DMBA-induced breast carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of carotenoid consumption on cardiometabolic risk biomarkers in peri- and post-menopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoid supplementation significantly increased plasma carotenoid levels, reduced LDL-cholesterol and atherogenic index, increased HDL-cholesterol, and improved oxidative stress and inflammation biomarkers, though endothelial dysfunction markers remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Peri- and post-menopausal women without prior cardiovascular disease symptoms but with some cardiometabolic risk factors.
effective_dosage: 415 mg of total carotenoids per week (from orange-carrot juice, tomato juice, and boiled spinach).
